Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Understanding controls on state-tranisition on Yellowstone's northern range
Award.AbstractNarration:
The extirpation and subsequent reintroduction of the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park has created a rare opportunity to understand how predators can change ecosystems. Wolves were extirpated from Yellowstone during the early twentieth century. Their loss led to a dramatic increase in the number of elk, which is believed to have subsequently caused substantial changes in vegetation along the park?s network of streams. Wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone in 1995. It was hypothesized that the reintroduction of wolves would cause a rapid restoration of riparian communities due to their effects on elk numbers and behavior. A 10-year experiment manipulating herbivory and water availability has thus far found little support for the idea that wolves have changed the ecosystem by releasing plants from herbivory by elk.

The abundance of elk in the Park has only recently declined to levels that were typical prior to the extirpation of wolves. Thus, it is plausible that there has not been sufficient time for vegetation to respond to reduced elk density resulting from wolf reintroduction. The 10-year experiment will be continued to better understand how climate, hydrology, and herbivory may control riparian ecosystems. The manipulative experiment will be supplemented with landscape-scale observations to provide a larger scale context in which to understand how wolves, elk, bison and weather interact to determine the state of the ecosystem.

The demonstrated interest of citizens in the unfolding story of wolves in Yellowstone assures that research findings will be communicated in the popular media. In addition, the research team will collaborate with Yellowstone National Park staff to offer citizen education to three million visitors to the park through interpretive programs. Additional broader impacts will result from graduate and undergraduate student training, and because data from this long term study will be made easily available to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The restoration of wolves to Yellowstone National Park in 1995-96 created a valuable opportunity to understand how predators shape ecosystems. Wolves were eliminated from Yellowstone National Park in the early 1900's. Unchecked by predation by wolves, the elk population that spent the winter on Yellowstone's northern range grew dramatically, from a few hundred animals to almost 20,000 animals in 1990. Intense grazing and browsing by elk caused major changes in the plant communities of the northern range, notably aspen and willow. Reproduction of aspen was effectively halted and willows disappeared from the banks of small streams. The loss of willows prevented beaver from building dams because beaver require willow for food and dam building materials. Cessation of dam building, in turn, caused many streams to incise deeply. The resulting, deep stream beds were effectively disconnected from the stream-side terraces that once provided ideal habitat for willow. Willows were left high and dry.

It has been claimed that the reintroduction of wolves has rapidly reversed the changes to the ecosystem that occurred during the period when wolves were absent. This view holds that wolves reduce elk numbers and change their behavior so that they feed less on woody plants like willow, allowing plants to recover from decades of excessive consumption by elk. However, an alternative view is that the current ecosystem has changed so much that wolf restoration alone is not enough to cause the ecosystem to return to its historic state. In particular, the reduction in availability of water to willows caused by the absence of beaver dams and the down-cutting of streams mean that moisture stress prevents willows from responding to reductions in browsing. The research team supported by this National Science Foundation Award has been working to determine which of these ideas is correct.

The centerpiece of the work is an experiment manipulating availability of water to willows using dams resembling those built by beaver, and manipulating browsing by elk and other large herbivores using fences. There were three treatments (dammed and unfenced, undammed and fenced, dammed and fenced) and a control (undammed and unfenced). Height and production of willows were measured annually in plots receiving the different treatments and in the controls. If reduction in browsing due to the effect of wolves is all that is required to restore willows, then willows in all treatment and control plots should be the same height and should produce the same amount of new plant tissue annually because water availability doesn't matter and because willows on controls are protected from browsing in the same way fenced willows are protected.

This is not what happened. The willows on control plots increased in height by about 25 inches in seventeen years, while willows on the dammed and fenced plots increased by more more than 200 inches. Willow that were dammed and not fenced and willows that were fenced and not dammed grew at rates about halfway between the controls and the dammed, fenced willows. This means that willows require beaver dams to recover rapidly from historic excessive browsing. However, beaver require willows for dam building. The mutual requirements of beaver for willows and willows for beaver have stabilized the ecosystem in a degraded state. The claimed “protection” of willows by wolves has done little to restore willow communities.

It could be that the sites where we conducted the experiment were unusual and did not reflect conditions across the northern range. The research team tested this possibility by comparing willow heights on experimental plots with willow heights on 27 other sites chosen randomly small streams on the northern range. Average heights of willows on control plots and on the randomly chosen plots were virtually identical. Moreover, these heights did not differ dramatically from heights measured in the early 1990's, before wolves were reintroduced.

This research showed that the nearly 100 year absence of wolves from the northern range of Yellowstone created conditions that cannot be rapidly reversed by their reintroduction. The loss of willows from excessive browsing caused the loss of dam building by beaver, which profoundly degraded habitat for willows. Willows will not recover unless those habitat conditions improve.

There is evidence that they are improving. Fifteen dams were established by beaver in four stream reaches of the northern range during 2015 - 2016. Willows responded immediately, growing almost as tall as willows on the dammed plots. This suggests that in the fullness of time, wolf reintroduction may ultimately lead to ecosystem restoration. However, it is not clear whether the newly established beaver colonies can persist. If they do, then the ecosystem appears to be headed toward restoration.
The research team is now studying these newly established beaver colonies to determine if dam building can be sustained over the long term, creating the habitat needed for restoration of willows in Yellowstone.
